title: Oxford, Columbia, and other top universities around the world took $60 million in donations from the wealthy family behind OxyContin
text:
Financial records show that at least 24 well-known educational institutions have accepted donations — from $25,000 to over $10 million — from the Sackler family in recent years.

The Sacklers own Purdue Pharma, the company that makes OxyContin, and have been involved in lawsuits over America's opioid epidemic.

Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories.

Prestigious universities around the world have accepted at least $60 million from the family that owns OxyContin maker Purdue Pharma over the past five years.

That's according to financial records reviewed by The Associated Press.

Schools have accepted the donations even as the company has become embroiled in lawsuits over its role in the opioid epidemic. Major beneficiaries of the Sackler family include the University of Oxford in England and Rockefeller, Cornell and Columbia universities in New York.

Read more: 6 museums and universities that are rejecting money from the wealthy family that's accused of fueling the opioid crisis

In total, at least two dozen universities have received gifts from the family since 2013. The gifts ranged from $25,000 to more than $10 million.

Some skeptics see the donations as an attempt to salvage the family's reputation and want to see the money returned.
description: Prestigious universities worldwide have accepted at least $60 million from the Sackler family over the past 5 years.
